title: Could this be Adobe's Gauge?
content:
The Adobe Media Player came bundled with the Adobe Reader 9 download recently. Having taken it for a spin, it appears to replicate what’s available at [http://tv.adobe.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20090525143719/http:/tv.adobe.com/ "http://tv.adobe.com"), only in an Adobe AIR wrapper so as to masquerade as a desktop application, apparently.

I was struck by the typeface used in the Media Player, and at Adobe TV—it’s not Cronos, or even Thomas Phinney’s Hypatia Sans, the most-recent sans serif from Adobe. What could it be?

I took a look at the lower-case “l,” and it appears to match up with the lower-case “l” in the “Fl” CS3/CS4 icon for Flash. I think that the font in question must be Robert Slimbach’s forthcoming tentatively-titled Gauge.

I rather like it—and can’t wait to see what the entire family looks like.

Another usage of the purported Gauge appears on Adobe’s Experience Design Team’s blog, at [http://xd.adobe.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20090525143719/http:/xd.adobe.com/). That site, like Adobe TV, is constructed in Flex, and uses Flash to render on-screen. (Viewing the site with the Flash 10 player shows off the enhanced anti-aliasing as compared with Flash 9, BTW.) Some folks have quibbled with the site’s usability—creating it in Flex/Flash takes away some HTML/browser usefulness with regards to navigation and accessibility—but the visual effect is wonderful (especially being able to embed all the fonts, and not resorting to using the SiFR workaround with HTML for setting headlines, for instance).

So—do you think the typeface is Slimbach’s forthcoming Gauge?

—Kent
author: Kent Steinbrenner

_Isn’t that look played out?_

Yes, the g and k stood out to me, as did the 5 and 8 and italic a. To me the sans-spur look is a bit dated too.

What would be really fascinating would be to know more about the design brief and Slimbach’s thinking behind the ’uncharacteristic’ elements.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090525143719im_/http:/typophile.com/files/siiko_5439.jpg)
I think Sii’s Apple comments are funnier than all get out, personally. Considering how much M$ gets slammed around, I think it’s fresh and funky that someone has something to jab Apple with.

I think its cool that Adobe bothered to tell us about it. Not having looked in enough detail yet to have a earnest opinion - my initial reaction is that it is the g that will have to grow on me.

Leaving the daxish a out of it, it feels just a little like a certain Underground font Paul Hunt made.

[http://www.p22.com/products/underground.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20090525143719/http:/www.p22.com/products/underground.html "http://www.p22.com/products/underground.html")

The lc l and the (relative) lack of stroke modulation are what make me think out that.
Eben if you spend a little more time with it you’ll see that it isn’t like Underground at all. Nothing against Underground, this is just a lot different.

Sorry if I gave the impression that I thought they were quite similar. They are not at all. The shapes are quite different. The impact of the two are as well. The reason I said what I did is that woven into the fabric of Clean there is just a certain melody or sensibility I felt like it they shared with Underground as a result of some forms and the low contrast. For example: the g in Clean does not share a shape with Underground at all. The are different at the script or stroke level! On the other hand there seems to be an an urge to a tempered geometric reductionism which is also present in Johnston’s Underground.

\>I think it’s fresh and funky that someone has something to jab Apple with.  
I think MS’s ads; the ones with the shopper/actors who have a free pass from the advertiser to buy anything, but have _no idea_ what they are going to do with those cheaper computers (copywriter’s fault), then select the cheap one even though it’s going to be free — that is a funny enough Apple jab, don’t you think? ;)

The “opinions are like ...” view that Paul references is really damaging to fruitful discussion.

My old teacher Popper said that the way knowledge progresses is through an attitude “I may be wrong and you may be right. Lets look at the evidence and discuss it, and try to find out the truth.”

I realize on matters of taste, as opposed to fact, it is more problematic, but still there’s no reason for people to take offense when they simply have different opinions.

That’s an opportunity to learn together.
